description.text:
A simple anti-vibration mount for the Runcam HD. I designed this to mount to the underside of my Syma X8C drone to help reduce jello. Uses 6 small rubber bands or o-rings to support the camera. Currently, angle adjustment is done by using different strength bands front to back, but a shim could be added to angle the entire assembly.

Including the 123d files as well. Different mounting methods could be attached to the base to something else like a bicycle or whatever else you may want a shock-mounted camera for.

Printer:

JGAurora A3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed the base with 30% infill laying flat, and with supports for the band hooks. The camera mount is printed at 100% infill standing upward from the front end, with supports for the hooks and button access holes. Camera mount is very thin, and doesn't have a large surface area when standing on end, so I printed with a brim to be safe.
Servo tape the base to whatever you want to mount on. Should work upside down or right-side up, but you will need to flip the camera orientation in software.

author: sahilmehtabme

description.text:
Hi
This is a Arm Samson out of Balanced Anihilation. http://balancedannihilation.org
all credits go to ComanderSpice and the crew of BA. Tools used
  • upspring
  • Blender
  • Mashlab

• download ba (http://balancedannihilation.org)
  • unpack the archive using 7zip

  • locate armsam.3ds

  • install upspring (http://springrts.com/wiki/Upspring)
  • load armsam.3ds

  • export .obj

  • install blender (http://www.blender.org/)
  • import .obj
  • create missing faces to close the bottomside (which isn't there for performance reasons)

  • export .stl

  • install meshlab http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/()
  • fix double vertices/close holes

font_size = 10
ring_width = 6

ring_thickness = 1.6

Christmas Heart created in ZBrush. The original bitmap of the Merry Christmas design was found on the net. The size is large as I'm away from home and my laptop doesn't have the power to decimate it in Zbrush and I don't have Meshlab installed. Should have a smaller version in about a week. Looking forward to seeing it printed as I'm also away form my 3d printer.

comments.author: Khanzi

comments.text:
In simplyfy 3d there is an option for layer fill. A creative way to bypass this error, is to use the integrated 3d program of the win10 it has a spluit option/keep both where it simpy cuts the model.
So Go in the model and slice it. find the missing layers. go in the 3d model vuilder of win 10 and cut in that spot. Or flip it 90 degrees and let it print it with missing layers and fill them with wood filler

title: Magic Band extender
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you've ever gone to Disney's Fort Wilderness Campground and Resort with a Class A Motorhome...you've probably felt like your arm was too short to reach the gate scanner when coming in the side gate to the Resort. Instead of hanging out the driver's side window to get your Magic Band close enough to trigger the gate...you can simply mount this THING on a 3/8" dowel of your choosing. Then fasten your Magic Band around the THING. Now you can extend your reach to the gate scanner comfortably, without hanging out the window like a crazy person. Enjoy!!! See ya'll at the Fort!!!

Revised the file...wider to better accept the magic band...and a little cleaner on the handle end.

MickeyBand_New file is a remixed version to accept the Latest version of Magic Band. Disney has changed the styling a bit...the RFID module is now screwed into the wrist band, and the front has a wider rounded appearance.

Reaming the rod opening

I found that the dimensions of the part are a little tight... If shoving a 3/8" dowel into the part...due to the force on the laminations the part will crack.

I recommend first to wrap the tube extension with electrical tape to keep compression on it...while slowly reaming with a 3/8" drill bit. Then...with the part smoothed out and properly dimensioned...you can apply a bit of glue to the tip of a dowel...and slip it into place without splitting the part.

comments.text: Now that's clever!!
comments.author: mikerockbennett

comments.text: Thanks!...  I am hoping to never have to hang out the window to trigger the gate again

author: chuggs

title: Smart Phone, iPod Touch or iPhone Smart Stand

description.text:
Simple smart folded stand for your Smart Phone, iPod Touch or iPhone.  
Easy to use self attaching stand for your smart device.  
Squeeze together when not in use and store in your pocket or bag.

Is this Yet another Smart Device stand? Yes and No - There is a lot of very creative and good designs on this site, but none fitted what I was looking for. A simple light weight hand free stand for my iPod Touch to watch potcasts everywhere. When not in use; easy to fold and store in my pocket. As the pictures show the stand is printed flat and gently folded before use. The material used is white ABS, but I am sure other materials will do as well (not tested). Printed using layer height of 0.3mm with 0.4mm nozzle diameter and solid infill. The hinge has a design thickness of 0.5mm and depending on slice program and layer height, it may be more or less regrid to fold. Try to make the hinge round and without sharp edges. Added STEP (.stp) file to make it easier to change and evolve the design :)

comments.text: I've printed this stand twice at the specifications and care instructions given.  Each time the hinges have failed after several hours - the plastic was flexible when warm, but as soon as it had cooled completely, it became quite brittle and snapped.  the stand also doesn't accomodate the width of an iPhone

comments.text: I'm not the happy owner of one of the new iPhones, but I think they are bigger than the original model. Primary I use the stand for my iPod Touch 4G and the size are right for that.

title: Thomas Minis Brio Style Train Tracks

description.text:
I could not find any printable tracks for the Thomas Minis trains, so I set out to create some, and learn more OpenSCAD along the way.

These started as modifications of the Remixed projects, so some code might be lifted directly, but as the project went along, most things ended up adjusted or rewritten in one way or another.

There are many (most?) of the available, modern Brio pieces recreated here, and a few non-standard parts. My print bed is only 120x120, so larger parts are available in the full size, and split into smaller pieces.

I tried to name the parts consistently, in a way that conveyed adequate info about them. Sections are separated by underscores ( _ ), and within those sections, info is separated with dashes ( - ). Sections marked with an asterisk ( * ) are not always present.

  • (PartGroup)(PartSubType)*(SplitPartIdentifier)(Dimensions)(BrioIdentifier).stl

An Example using all sections: QuadCurve-Cross_SmR_PART_Xof4_L1.5-C.25_X

  • PartGroup: QuadCurve-Cross
  • PartSubType: SmR (small radius)
  • SplitPartIdentifier: PART_Xof4 (broken into 4 equal parts)
  • Dimensions: L1.5-C.25 (straight Length - Circumference)
  • BrioIdentifier: X

All dimensions are defined toward the top of the SCAD file, but for naming the important values are:

  • L - Length = 110mm
  • LgR - Large Radius Curve = 150mm
  • SmR - Small Radius Curve = 67.5mm

I test printed many parts along the way, but in their final form, the following pieces have been test printed:

  • Acc_Connector
  • Curve_SmR_L-Str_L.75-C.125_O1-P1
  • Curve_SmR_R-Str_L.75-C.125_O1-P1
  • DoubleCurve_SmR_L-R-Str_PART_1of3_L1.5-C.25_T
  • DoubleCurve_SmR_L-R-Str_PART_2of3_L1.5-C.25_T
  • Curve_Double_L_LgR-SmR_C.125-C.25
  • QuadCurve-Cross_SmR_PART_Xof4_L1.5-C.25_X (Printed 4)

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 - .4

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Most parts can be printed flat, bottom down, without support or raft, with the following exceptions:

  • Acc_Connector: I printed in groups of 8 or more together on a raft.
  • Acc_Buffer: Printed bottom down, with supports everywhere. Puts a couple between the horizontal bars. Pushed right out with a screwdriver.

Assembly:

If you find the connectors to be a bit tight when pushing them down on a piece, try to push the connector in from the bottom, or the piece down onto the connector.

author: JeenS

title: Battery cases for Fujifilm NP-95 batteries

description.text:
This battery organizer is designed to hold Fujifilm NP-95 batteries. The tolerances are designed to hold the original batteries and various third party batteries with slightly different (thicker) wrapping.

The big hole in the back is used to push them out and the tiny edge on the front keeps the battery from falling out.

They are not meant to act as a dust cover, but a way to organize the batteries nicely and to seperate empty batteries from fully charged ones.

Printing should be easy. I got good and consistent results on an Original Prusa i3 MKII with the following setup:

  • Sliced in Simplify3D
  • Printed standing upright with the back on the print bed
  • PLA
  • 0.4mm nozzle
  • 2 Shells
  • 0.2mm resolution
  • Zero infill to make them flexible, but you can experiment with that
  • 5 Top and bottom layers (stiffens the front and back)

description.text:
Earth Prime Inc designed this 2" hydroponic net-cup so that we could hack the flaws in our Beta Rendition Vertical hydroponic system. With this netcup, we make our required custom part water tight, and reliable so that we do not have to mass produce many expensive parts until funds are available Turns out, our hydroponic net-cup can help you with your DIY Vertical Hydroponic builds too rather than spending $750 on a Tower Garden.

Most DIY vertical hydroponic gardens run into a similar issue (unless the systems are run horizontally and stacked vertically). That issue is with the net-cup.

The way it is currently mass produce, the edge is designed to sit flush with the surface it is in contact with. When you stick your rockwool bound moist plants into the hole, the water does not continue draining downward. Instead, water wicks onto the rockwool and plant mass and over the edge of the water container onto the ground.

As a solution, we designed a net-cup with more "Pitch" or slant to the cup. In this manner, the slope given to the plant add physical support as well as precise water drainage.

Because our planter box system has a little bit of pitch (16degrees) and has a flat surface to fit, you may want to adjust the part to fit your specific project. First meaning you may want to increase the angle from 20 up to 40 degrees. Secondly, you may want to round the lip of the cup if you are inserting it onto a PVC pipe. For this, figure the circumference of the pipe. The netcup is 2.25 inches with the lip. That should give you the arc you need for the face to fit flush.

Hope this Helps. Hope you Enjoy!

Notes:

To be updated upon consultation from our printing partners.
The extended solid portion is to keep water from running over the edge.

title: Dice Tower “La Garita del Castillo San Felipe del Morro”
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
¡El compañero perfecto para tus aventuras de juegos!

Torre de dados La Garita del Castillo San Felipe del Morro. ¡Con esta torre de dados puedes tirar tus dados como lo hicieron los españoles en el siglo XVI!

La torre está diseñada con tres escalones para rodar los dados adecuadamente. De la base a la abertura la torre mide 4-1 / 8in (105.33mm), de la base a la tapa de la "garita" que mide 5-7 / 8in (148.55mm) y en el punto más ancho la base mide 4 -5 / 8 pulg (116.79mm)

No te pierdas la oportunidad de volver atrás en el tiempo y ser un conquistador haciendo un roll perfecto con esta épica Garita del Castillo San Felipe del Morro.

Si quieres aprender un poco como se diseñó la torre de dados puedes ver los videos en estos enlaces
https://youtu.be/G0Un8oitA_g
https://youtu.be/xcJOzvrKv74

English:
The perfect companion for your tabletop adventures!

“La Garita del Castillo San Felipe del Morro” dice tower. With this dice tower you can roll your dice as the Spaniards did back in the 16th century!

This design features a three tear slant for effective dice rolling. From the base to the opening the tower measures 4-1/8in (105.33mm), from the base to the top of the “garita” it measures 5-7/8in (148.55mm) and at the widest point the base measures 4-5/8in (116.79mm)

Don’t miss out on your opportunity to go back in time and be a “conquistador” getting a perfect roll with this epic “Garita del Castillo San Felipe del Morro” dice tower.

If you want to learn how the tower was designed, you can see the videos here https://youtu.be/G0Un8oitA_g
https://youtu.be/xcJOzvrKv74

0.2

10%

Imprima lentamente en PLA para que todos los detalles finos estén presentes en la torre terminada.

title: 3Dprinted Lunar Phase Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Un9RubtGH0
https://youtu.be/L0lwI6Ri8fw

3D printed Lunar Phase Clock, designed by G4lile0 2016

Update 25/02/2017 new code version V 4.0
Clock Status is now stored on the RTC NVRAM, this mean that after power failure, clock will return to the old status, moon mode, and alarm configuration instead of load defaul configuration.

Since there isn't a SuperMoon everyday, make one for your bedside table!!

If you don't know what to print with your 3D printer, here you have an easy project.
Build a 3D printed Lunar Phase Clock for your desk.

Features: (check the video)

  • Open Tools (Ubuntu / FreeCAD / Arduino)
  • Open Source / Hardware
  • Cheap HW (Arduino, cheap LCD..)
  • Only 79 grams of filament.
  • Precise Lunar Phase Simulation
  • Detailed 3D printed Lunar model
    by Dexter_New_Materials (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1014620)
  • Alarm
  • Wake-light alarm mode
  • Date
  • Thermometer
  • Hygrometer
  • Lamp mode
  • Moon FX modes (Relax, Party... )
  • Bright control
  • Adjustable tilt

Parts List:

  • Arduino compatible Nano (Atmel ATmega328)
  • 0,96'' OLED 128x64 with SSD1306 chip
  • APA102C led strip (18 leds)
  • Tiny RTC (DS1307 real time clock + 24C32 EEPROM)
  • DTH11
  • Buzzer
  • 3 Push Buttons

Source available on GitHub:
https://github.com/G4lile0/Arduino_3dprinted_Lunar_Phase_Clock

For further info:
http://www.instructables.com/id/3Dprinted-Lunar-Phase-Clock/

Video Created under Ubuntu with OpenShot video Editor.
Music : Sport Action

Reloj con fase Lunar impreso en 3D diseñado por G4lile0

Como no todos los días hay una SuperLuna ¡¡fabrícate una para la mesilla de noche!!

Si no sabes que imprimir con tu impresora en 3d, aquí tienes un reloj con fase lunar para tu mesa.

  • Creado solo con herramientas libres (Ubuntu / Freecad / Arduino)
  • Open Source / Hardware
  • Electrónica económica (Arduino, LCD)
  • Tan solo 79 gramos de filamento
  • Precisa simulacion de la fase lunar
  • Modelo detallado de la luna
    by Dexter_New_Materials (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1014620)
  • Reloj analogico y digital
  • Alarma con simulación de amananecer
  • Alarma
  • Fecha
  • Termometro
  • Monitor de Humedad
  • Lampara
  • Modos Demo (Disco /Relax...)
  • Control de brillo
  • Inclinación regulable

Componentes:

  • Arduino compatible Nano (Atmel ATmega328)
  • 0,96'' OLED 128x64 with SSD1306 chip
  • APA102C led strip (18 leds)
  • Tiny RTC (DS1307 real time clock + 24C32 EEPROM)
  • DTH11
  • Buzzer
  • 3 botones.

Fuentes disponibles en GitHub:

https://github.com/G4lile0/Arduino_3dprinted_Lunar_Phase_Clock

Para mas información:
http://www.instructables.com/id/3Dprinted-Lunar-Phase-Clock/

Vídeo creado bajo Ubuntu con OpenShot video Editor.
Musica : Sport Action

comments.text: The moon could be made darker by using some black (or a dark grey) spray paint to lightly dust the surface.  The idea is to permit much of the light from the LEDs to shine through, but give a dark appearance when the non-illuminated areas are viewed from the outside.   The brightness of the LEDs should be increased to compensate.
comments.author: cadcoke5

comments.text: Thanks Joe, effect sure will be great, but It will be difficult to choose the quantity or type of spray,  another user suggested to add an inner "moon" or semi sphere to blur the light from the led, to create a shadow halo.
comments.author: cadcoke5

comments.text: I am not certain what you want the internal sphere to accomplish by blurring the light. You already have some internal baffles. Perhaps they should be colored black, to prevent light getting through a baffle, and illuminating the adjacent area.

comments.text:
Hi Fotis,
Bright value is stored in the arduino ram, if there is a power cut, it will reset to the default value.
I will release a new version that store these values (Alarm, Bright, status.....) in the RTC's NVRAM
Will be great if you publish a make of your own moon clock :)

comments.text: Hello galile0 - thank you very much for posting this, as well as the Instructable that walks through the build. I am 90% there, but when I try to compile and upload the sketch lunar_clock_v3.ino I get a "sketch too big" error.
comments.author: BigLazyB

comments.text:
Hi, Maybe you are using the Nano v2 ( ATmega168) that only have 1kb, you will need the Nano v3.x (ATmega328) with 2kb of flash.
If you have the Nano V3.x be sure to select the "Arduino Duemilanove or Nano w/ ATmega328" from the Tools > Board menu.
comments.author: BigLazyB

comments.text: Hi galile0,
comments.author: galile0

comments.text: Try to use the Arduino Sdk 1.6.12, as when I use this version to compile it, the sketch uses 29.952 bytes (97%) of program storage space, global variables use 55% of dynamic memory.
comments.author: BigLazyB

comments.text: Wow! galile0 -- thank you very much. Your lite version did the trick (was compiling with 1.6.3, I went ahead and tried your revised sketch before reverting to 1.6.12) -- compiles at 28,080 bytes -- everything is now working perfectly on the breadboard - time to start assembling.
comments.author: galile0

comments.text:
Great to know that the lite version did the trick.
I'm still surprised with the difference of size, maybe is related to the libraries. ( I have a copy of them on me github)
it would be great if you could post a photo of your finish model on thingiverse :) and also if you could subscribe to the youtube channel .
I'm sure it will be ready for Christmas delivery :)

title: 18650 holder for e-bike and other projects

description.text:
This is a tray to use for an 18650 battery holder. It has 4 channels for holding 8 AWG (3.5mm diameter) copper wire. I will be featuring this in my ebike project video series on YouTube on my channel Power Playground. I also have a small FreeCAD tutorial where I show how to make a specific part of this model.

I have uploaded a 3x8 tray model and a 4x8 tray as well as the FreeCAD files for both!

FreeCAD Tutorial: https://youtu.be/enenIERNC7Q
FreeCAD Tutorial Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMjfntGK5aY4qRy4QJr6YiAilvcR90qDj
Ebike Project Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMjfntGK5aY6NjuNRu5GaXr_bncQPM0ES

Subscribe to https://www.youtube.com/user/powerplayground so you don't miss out on my latest videos!

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

No

No

25%

I used a sparse infill and used 4 layers for the top and bottom.

This Thing simplifies mass production of spools for filament coils up to 100 m in length and with any coil diameter. It can be made in two sizes, the 30 mm one is nice for ~50 m coils and the 40 mm should fit up to 100 m coils.  The spools are made from simple cardboard cut outs and small printed clips. Prints clean and quick.

EDIT: Here is a video of 9 st 50 m spools in paralell! The clips work great no hiccups thus far.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D-pQqZkbHng&feature=youtube_gdata_player This is a very quick and simple way of making spools for lots of different loose coils of filament you might have. Print time for a working, usable spool is 15 minutes, double this if you print the hub as well, it is optional.
Plastic required for a spool is LESS THAN 4 GRAMS! gasp
Assembly is super quick as well :)
The only drawback is that you need some cardboard. UPDATE1: I have now made 5 of them and I recommend you to include the hub piece, it makes getting the second piece of cardboard on centered a bit easier. UPDATE2: I have uploaded the version for larger coils as well now. The clip and the hub has been enlarged by 10 mm to accept 100m filament coils. Use as previous. 40 mm versions are named flatclip 40mm100m.stl and CORE solid v2 40mm.st

  • Slice the clip
    Recommended settings:
    6 shells, no infill, no solid layers = Smooth printing and no cleanup.
    This will also give the clip the correct flex.

  • Print 4 clips per spool, ~15 min / 4 st
    I used an Ultimaker with 0,2 mm layer thickness, PLA and 80 mm/s feed speed.

  • Optional: Central hub
    Print the hub, its the "CORE_solid_v2.stl" file. The hub also functions as a spacer (60 mm width / spool) which is neat if you plan to store and use many spools on the same axis.
    Print time ~15 minutes, suggested slicing: 2 shells, no solid layers, no infill = No cleanup and smooth printing.
    EDIT: Make sure your two shells stick together right from the start or your hub will be floppy.

  • Cut the cardboard
    While they are printing, cut two circular cardboard disks with a diameter to match your coil diameter+100mm. If you are making lots, you might use a piece of string to get the shape right. (This is really quick work).

  • Place the filament coil on one of the cardboard disks and stick 4 clips just inside the coil, equally spaced. (See pic.) Use your thumb to secure the clips. (See pic.)
    Insert the hub part now it you made one!
    Place the next cardboard cut out on top and press down between the clip teeth with your thumb (See pic.)
    • Extra info:
    I needed about 12 spools so I took my time browsing for other solutions here, and let myself go a bit crazy trying different designs for the clip. So the clip is thoroughly tested. If you want the .stp files for the other feasible clip designs I tried please ask me in the comments (see pic in comments).
    I did the 3D design in 123D CAD from Autodesk, it's 100% free at http://www.123dapp.com

comments.text: I just wanted to share a quick thing I made. It's a label to paste onto the side of a piece of cardboard for the spool that has fields for you to put in the maker of the filament, what type of filament it is, print settings, as well as notes about the print or filament. Thought it might come in handy. It prints for 11''x17'' paper, but I'll include an 8 1/2'' x 11'' version too. Resolution has been double from normal print sizes, so scale to 50% and you should be golden. Cheers!

description.text:
This is a self supporting 1 piece plastic part that requires no assembly.  The adapter allows you to use your iPhone 5 to capture still images, video, or FaceTime content from under the microscope.  Zoom and focus are provided by the microscope.  The adapter is capable of adjusting to eye pieces that vary 30mm +/- 2mm. This part was originally designed in ABS.  PLA will likely seem a lot stiffer where the eye piece flexes.  
Enjoy!  
-Greg

I have included a .x3g file for this part.  This file will for for the Makerbot Replicator 2X.  The file will build using the right extruder (ABS material), make a raft, 300 micron layer setting, build plate heated to 110C, Support turned off, grown vertically rested on its flat base, density is 5%.  Build time is 58 minutes.  
If you use the .stl I recommend using settings similar to what I have above.  I have not tried making this part in PLA.  The part works perfectly fine on the 300 mircon layer setting. My extruder tends to print over sized so the undercuts I have to support the bottom of the phone are over-sized to compensate for the part coming in about 0.3mm undersized.  When print is finished just peel off the raft and your done!  
Good Luck!

title: Adjustable focus HD FPV goggles for Connex Prosight or Raspberry Pi HD FPV Broadcast project

description.text:
These goggles have 2 different versions, on utilizes the Raspberry PI HD broadcast project and a cheap dedicated 5 inch Raspberry Pi screen. The other has a direct HDMI input and is suitable for an HD link such as the Connex Prosight.

I have made the focal length adjustable because none of the off-the shelf goggles I have tried have I been able to get a decent focus for my prescription. I am sure this must be the case for other old people like me! The only modification I have made since doing the video is an optional lens rack to take 2 fresnel lenses if you cant get a clear focus with one. You might be able to do without the Carlson lens if you use 2 fresnels.

Instructions are on these 2 videos:
https://youtu.be/jgBXyjoMyts
https://youtu.be/tNXsQrTrK-M

If the lens mask does not quite fit your face just use more foam!

Refs:
Wifibroadcast – Analog-like transmission of live video data Project

https://befinitiv.wordpress.com/wifibroadcast-analog-like-transmission-of-live-video-data/

author: lorenzostefanelli

title: Asus Zenwatch 2 TPU Case for 1.63-inch Display

description.text:
This is my first try at a TPU case for zenwatch 2. This came out pretty good and fits well. I printed in black TPU at 224 nozzel and 60 bed. I used .2 layer height with 1.2 thickness. Be sure to print with the 'face' side down on the bed.

I also uploaded a another case for zenwatch 2 that is good for printing with PLA or PETG. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1864147)

I don't think this case would work with PLA. Give it a try with TPU and let me know how it works. I'm am going to wear mine a few days and if it ends up falling off I will create a new version to fix it.

Maker Select 3p (wanhao duplicator i3v2)

I designed this Handle for a drill chuck from a cheap Habor Freight drill. If you want to make one, but don't want to buy a drill just for this, I've seen them at Lowe's for about $7.

You will need a bolt for mounting the chuck to the handle. It is a 3" long 3/8"-24(TPI) hex bolt. The thread on the bolt is a standard for smaller drill chucks so it should work with any drill chuck.

I made this to hold drill bits and counter sink bits, so that I can reem and clean any holes my 3d prints.

Whenever I export .stl files from Inventor it changes the scale. So I just scale my prints up by 25.4 in the slicer.

remixed_from.author: KHecker
remixed_from.title: ABS indicator holder to level Rep 2 build plate

remixed_from.author: jetty
remixed_from.title: YADIH - Yet Another Dial Indicator Holder For Replicator

title: Makerbot Replicator 2 or 2X Build Plate Indicator Base

description.text:
There are many indicator bases available on Thingaverse, but I chose to make my own because I thought some existing concepts over constrained the design by trying to pick up on both rods with arcs or v grooves. This design will pick up the rear most 8mm guide rod and align itself. The rest of the gauge block is a flat surface allowing the distance between rods and the rods diameter to vary without affecting the height of the block on the rods. Craft magnets are used to hold the block down vertically. After heating my build plate I use a feeler gauge to set my nozzle height to .006" above the rear most leveling screw, set my indicator to zero, and level the front to screws in relation to the back most. With this block I can consistently get these 3 points on my build plate within +/-.0005" of each other. Enjoy!
-Greg

Indicator:
http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-travel-machinists-dial-indicator-623.html Magnets:
Harbor Freight "Craft Magnets" 10 piece ceramic magnets for $0.47. They measure approximately .525" on the OD. 5 will fit in each hole of the block. Sorry I didn't see them on the website when I looked. .x3g files is included for Makerbot Replicator 2X. ABS, 200 micron build height, 25% density, 110C build plate, raft on, support off. The side of the block (top) where the magnets and indicator are inserted is grown face down to give the best quality surface to where the rods ride. If the holes for the magnets are a little tight, I recommend using the ID measuring jaws on a metal caliper. Set them to .525" and tighten the set screw. Spinning these in the bore seemed to fix the slight bulge at the hole opening. STL files are included. I have not tried printing in PLA.
